thread.title_full: Alexander Fehling springs to action as lawyer in ‘Labyrinth,’ ‘Homeland’ | Boston Herald

author: Stephen Schaefer
title: Alexander Fehling springs to action as lawyer in ‘Labyrinth,’ ‘Homeland’
text:
Germany’s Alexander Fehling gets his big-screen introduction to American movie­goers this season with the fact-based German-language “Labyrinth of Lies.”
Fehling, 34 and comfortably conversant in English, is also currently co-starring in his first-ever American TV series: Season 5 of “Homeland,” in which he plays Claire Danes’ lawyer boyfriend, Jonas Happich.
“Labyrinth” tells the true story of the Frankfurt public prosecutor who in 1958 became the first German to hold trials against his country­men’s WWII Nazi war crimes at Auschwitz.
In the process, “Labyrinth” reveals how Germany came to terms with its gruesome history.
“The subject matter, the story, is so powerful,” Fehling said from Beverly Hills.
His character, lawyer Johann Radmann, is “a composite of three prosecutors who lived and worked those cases at the time.
“I had the good fortune to speak to one of them. He was my age at the time and he told me how at first he didn’t believe all this stuff — he thought it was propaganda.
“Then he did his research and understood it was true. He said, ‘In the end, we just went to work.’
“It sounds so simple, but it helped me. You don’t want to play a character who all the time is emotionally involved — you want the audience to suffer, not yourself.”
Fehling’s first big break was as the German soldier in Quentin Tarantino’s “Inglourious Basterds” whose birthday celebration in a tavern climaxed with gunfire and carnage.
“Homeland” is particularly apt because it’s filming all 12 episodes in Fehling’s hometown, Berlin.
While “a set is a set” anywhere an actor goes, he likens this American production to “a train that goes and never stops. It’s different because you never know what’s going to happen in the next episode; you don’t know your character’s arc or where your character is going to end up.
“That’s pretty new to me. This is a challenge that I take as an opportunity.
“And working in English so continuously,” he added, “really helps me — and it’s fun.”
(“Labyrinth of Lies” opens Friday.)
